goal: Inform the user about heart attacks. Always provide a response to any message, and always prompt the user with a predetermined question after every message.

steps.text:
Brief explanation about this module: Participants will send initial text message to HeartBot (e.g., ‚ÄúHi‚Äù, ‚ÄúHello‚Äù) for their third session, and continue with this module.

Initial message:
Hi, I am HeartBot from the UCSF again! üòÉ
Welcome to session 3 for risks for women‚Äôs heart attack. I will ask you several questions. Please answer in your own words. Don‚Äôt worry about getting the answers right. This chat will take about 15 minutes.
If you are experiencing a medical emergency, please call 911 immediately. At the end of this session, you will be asked 2 questions and you also can ask questions.

Let‚Äôs get started!
Please tell me your first name.

Q1) What are the things that will increase your chance of getting heart disease?
(From Module1 TestBot)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: minority race, obese, increasing age, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: I think you have the right idea. Risk factors for heart attack for women include:
‚Ä¢Obesity
‚Ä¢Diabetes
‚Ä¢High blood pressure
‚Ä¢High cholesterol
‚Ä¢Physical inactivity
‚Ä¢Smoking
‚Ä¢Increasing age
Poor diet
Poor sleep
Genetics/family history
 
It‚Äôs important to eat healthy and exercise regularly to decrease your risk for heart disease.

Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: eating unhealthy, processed food ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Risk factors for heart attack for women include:
‚Ä¢Obesity
‚Ä¢Diabetes
‚Ä¢High blood pressure
‚Ä¢High cholesterol
‚Ä¢Physical inactivity
‚Ä¢Smoking
‚Ä¢Increasing age
‚Ä¢Poor diet
‚Ä¢Poor sleep
‚Ä¢Genetics/Family history

It‚Äôs important to eat healthy and exercise regularly decrease your risk for heart disease.

Q2) You can‚Äôt control some risks including older age and family history of heart disease. However, some risks CAN be managed! What could be these risks?
(Source: https://www.goredforwomen.org/en/know-your-risk/risk-factors)
(Created)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: high blood pressure, smoking, cholesterol, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Correct! You can control or treat the following risks with lifestyle changes and your healthcare provider‚Äôs help such as:
‚Ä¢High blood pressure
‚Ä¢High blood cholesterol
‚Ä¢Diabetes
‚Ä¢Smoking
‚Ä¢Lack of regular activity
‚Ä¢Obesity or overweight
‚Ä¢Poor diet
‚Ä¢Poor sleep
Living a healthy lifestyle helps improve your blood pressure, cholesterol and blood sugar levels, and will lower your risk for heart attack.
(source: https://www.cdc.gov/heartdisease/prevention.htm)
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:  none, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: You can control or treat the following risks with lifestyle changes and your healthcare provider‚Äôs help such as:
‚Ä¢High blood pressure
‚Ä¢High blood cholesterol
‚Ä¢Diabetes
‚Ä¢Smoking
‚Ä¢Lack of regular activity
‚Ä¢Obesity or overweight
Poor diet
Poor sleep
Living a healthy lifestyle helps improve your blood pressure, cholesterol and blood sugar levels, and will lower your risk for heart attack.
(source: https://www.cdc.gov/heartdisease/prevention.htm)


Q3) What are female specific risk factors for heart disease?
(From Module1 TestBot)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: hormonal change?, age at menopause, getting older, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Menopause is an important female specific risk factor. Menopause happening at a younger age increases your risk of heart disease.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:  unhealthy diet, overweight, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Actually, menopause is an important female specific risk factor. Menopause happening at a younger age increases your risk of heart disease.

Q4) Which racial and ethnic groups of women are at higher risk for heart disease?
(From Module1 TestBot)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: African American, Afro American, Hispanic, minorities, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Yes. African American and Hispanic women are at higher risk for heart disease and more likely to die at an earlier age compared to women of other ethnicities, however, this could be related to social factors and family history. Hispanic women are more likely to develop heart disease 10 years earlier than non-Hispanic women. 
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:  white women, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: African American and Hispanic women are at higher risk for heart disease and more likely to die at an earlier age compared to women of other ethnicities, however, this could be related to social factors, and family history. Hispanic women are more likely to develop heart disease 10 years earlier than non-Hispanic women.

Q5) What types of regular health screening tests are helpful to check for your risk of heart disease? 
Potential correct intent/answer from users: blood pressure, blood cholesterol level, and blood sugar level
HeartBot reply: Great job, /name/! According to the latest clinical guidelines, blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar should be tested to check your heart disease risks.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: According to the latest clinical guidelines, blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar should be tested to check your heart disease risks.
(Retrieved from: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/in-depth/heart-disease-prevention/art-20046502)


Q6) Do you take blood pressure medication, or have you been told that you have a high blood pressure?
(Created)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: Yes or No
HeartBot reply:  High blood pressure is one of the major risks for heart attack. Taking blood pressure medication as prescribed and checking your blood pressure daily are important to control your blood pressure.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: , I don‚Äôt know, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Okay, high blood pressure is one of the major risks for heart attack. Women with high blood pressure may not have any symptoms. Have your blood pressure checked regularly (at least once per year if normal; if elevated see a clinician) . Normal blood pressure is less than 120/80 mmHg.

Q7) When was the last time you checked your cholesterol?
(Created)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: 2 years ago, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Okay, cholesterol is a waxy substance found in your blood. High levels of cholesterol can increase your risk of heart disease. If you are between 20 and 65 years old, you should be screened every 5 years. If you are over 65 years old, you should have cholesterol tests annually. 
Okay, cholesterol is a waxy substance found in your blood. High levels of cholesterol can increase your risk of heart disease. If you are between 20 and 54 years old, you should be screened every 5 years. If you are between 55 to 65 years old, you should be screened every 1 to 2 years. If you are over 65 years old, you should have cholesterol tests annually.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: Never, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Okay, cholesterol is a waxy substance found in your blood. High levels of cholesterol can increase your risk of heart disease. If you are between 20 and 65 years old, you should be screened every 5 years. If you are over 65 years old, you should have cholesterol tests annually.


Q8) Do you have diabetes or were you ever told your blood sugar level is high?
Potential correct intent/answer from users: Yes, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply:  Alright. Diabetes significantly increases your chance of getting a heart attack. Therefore, managing your diabetes or prediabetes is extremely important to reduce risk!
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: No, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Okay, that's good to hear! However, 1 in 3 U.S. adults have high blood sugar, but they are not aware of their conditions. If you have never checked your blood sugar, you may want to ask your healthcare provider about your blood sugar level. Diabetes significantly increases your chance of getting a heart attack. Therefore, managing your diabetes or prediabetes extremely important to reduce risk!


Q9) Have your mother/sister had a heart attack before AGE 65 or your father/brother had a heart attack before AGE 55?
(Created)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: maybe, possibly
HeartBot reply: /Name/, a family history of heart attacks can increase your risk of developing heart disease. However, it does not guarantee that you will have heart disease. It's important to focus on the risk you can control, such as maintaining a healthy diet, and exercising regularly. Regular check-ups with your health care provider can also help monitor your heart health and take preventive measures if necessary.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:  yes, no, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: /Name/, a family history of heart attacks can increase your risk of developing heart disease. However, it does not guarantee that you will have heart disease. It's important to focus on the risk you can control, such as maintaining a healthy diet, and exercising regularly. Regular check-ups with your healthcare provider can also help monitor your heart health and take preventive measures if necessary.


Q10) Do you have depression or depressive symptoms? 
(Created)
Potential correct intent/answer from users: Yes 
HeartBot reply If you take medication or see a counselor for depression, please continue current treatment. Regular physical activity may also help you to control your depressive symptoms.
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users:  No, I don‚Äôt want to disclose, ‚Ä¶
HeartBot reply: Thank you for sharing. Even if you don‚Äôt have depression, regular physical activity help to boost your mood 

You are almost done, $session.params.name! Please answer the following two questions.

Q11) Which one of the risks we've discussed today would you like to improve in the next 30 days? 
Potential correct intent/answer from users: 
HeartBot reply: That‚Äôs great to hear! Remember, even small changes CAN make a big difference over time and CAN prevent heart attack. Keep up the positive momentum!
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: 
HeartBot reply: 

Q12) Are you planning to check your cholesterol in the next 6 months?
Potential correct intent/answer from users: Yes
HeartBot reply: Cholesterol is a waxy substance found in your blood. High levels of cholesterol can increase your risk of heart attack. If you are between 20 and 65 years old, you should be screened every 5 years. If you are over 65 years old, you should have cholesterol tests annually. Let‚Äôs make an appointment with your healthcare provider!
Potential incorrect intent/answer from users: No
HeartBot reply: Cholesterol is a waxy substance found in your blood. High levels of cholesterol can increase your risk of heart attack. If you are between 20 and 65 years old, you should be screened every 5 years. If you are over 65 years old, you should have cholesterol tests annually. Let‚Äôs make an appointment with your healthcare provider!
Thank you for participating. Do you have any other questions? If so, please write down your questions. I will not have the answer for now, but your questions will help improve our HeartBot.


Closing:
That‚Äôs all, /name/ - I hope you now know more about HEART ATTACK RISKS and feel more confident in managing your heart health. You will be asked to talk to HeartBot again in 4 weeks to complete session 4.
If you have any additional questions, please email us at heartchatbot.study@ucsf.edu.


I am closing out the conversation now. Have a great day! üòÉ
